member.name: P:Microsoft.LearningComponents.Manifest.MetadataNodeReader.MetadataNamespaces
member.summary: Returns an object that can be used for resolving namespaces in an XPathNavigator.SelectSingleNode call. The metadata namespace will be identified by the "lom:" prefix. The "adlcp:" namespace is also included because of the <adlcp:location> node.

remarks.para: For SCORM 2004, the metadata namespace is (http://ltsc.ieee.org/xsd/LOM).
For SCORM 1.2, the metadata namespace is (http://www.imsglobal.org/xsd/imsmd_rootv1p2).

member.name: P:Microsoft.LearningComponents.Manifest.MetadataNodeReader.Lom
member.summary: Points to the <lom> node in the metadata. This may be in a different file than the manifest, if the Location exists. Returns null if Location is a URI outside of the package.

member.name: P:Microsoft.LearningComponents.Manifest.MetadataNodeReader.Location
member.summary: Gets the location of the metadata information, if it is external to the manifest. If this value returns a location that indicates the metadata information is not in the package, then other properties in this object will not read their values. If the location is within the package or if there is no location specified, this object will provide properties to read and parse those values.
member.remarks:
Returns null if there is no <adlcp:location> node in the metadata.
If this is an absolute URI, String.Empty is returned from GetTitle and GetDescriptions. Absolute URI's are valid according to SCORM, but are not supported by this reader.

member.summary: Indicates whether a navigation would be valid if it were to be performed.
member.param: The navigation command to test.
The destination activity, if this is a choice navigation.
member.returns: True if the navigation would be valid, false otherwise.

remarks.para: This makes a partial copy of the activity tree for processing and attempts to perform a navigation on that copy. This may result in poor performance if this is called many times, but the alternative is to duplicate most of the sequencing code with lots of special cases for changes of state that should have happened but could not because of the temporary nature of this request. This makes it a maintenance nightmare, for something that should only rarely be called anyway except in the case of LoadTableOfContents.
The case of LoadTableOfContents is tough, but steps are taken within that method to reduce the number of calls to this method to a bare minimum.

member.name: T:Microsoft.LearningComponents.PackageReader
member.summary: Provides read-only access to the files contained within a single package.
member.remarks:
PackageReader is an abstract class which provides an application with a consistent way of accessing content within a package, regardless of how the package is stored. Microsoft Learning Components provides the following implementations of PackageReader:
FileSystemPackageReader provides access to a package stored in the file system.
ZipPackageReader provides access to a package stored in a zipped file.
LrmPackageReader provides access to a package stored in an LRM file.
Microsoft.LearningComponents.SharePoint.SharePointPackageReader provides access to a package stored in a Windows SharePoint Services document library. This class is defined in Microsoft.LearningComponents.SharePoint.dll.
PackageReader implements IDisposable. Always call the Dispose method when finished with a PackageReader object, or use a using statement, to ensure that unmanaged resources are explicitly and properly released.

member.summary: TODO

member.name: M:Microsoft.LearningComponents.PackageReader.Create(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Returns either a ZipPackageReader or LrmPackageReader, according to the type of package provided.
member.param: The zipped package (.zip or .ims) or .lrm package.
member.returns: A PackageReader that reads the supplied package.
member.exception: is null.
member.remarks:
The stream is analyzed to determine if it is a zipped file. If it is not, it is assumed to be an .lrm package. In either case, the correctness of the package is not checked here, but rather in subsequent calls to e.g. CreateManifestNavigator.
The PackageReader that is returned uses the current user's credentials to read files from the package.

member.name: T:Microsoft.LearningComponents.FileSystemPackageReader
member.summary: Provides read-only access to the files contained within a single package that is stored in the file system.

remarks.para: The package can be stored on the local hard drive, removable storage, or on a network file share accessible via a mapped drive letter or UNC path.
See PackageReader for examples of how classes based on PackageReader (such as this one) can be used.
The only state maintained by FileSystemPackageReader is the file system path to the package, which is set in the constructor and never changes for the lifetime of the object.

is a null reference.

member.name: T:Microsoft.LearningComponents.LrmPackageReader
member.summary: Provides read-only access to the files contained within a single package, when the package is stored in LRM format. This is most commonly *.lrm files. The reader will only allow reading packages that are single Learning Resource files. Other types of files (for instance, multi-LR LRMs, license files or remote content files) will cause exceptions when files from the package are requested.

remarks.para: The LRM file can be stored on the local hard drive, removable storage, or on a network file share accessible via a mapped drive letter or UNC path. However, note that performance may be very poor if the file name is a UNC path.
This class can be used to import a package contained in an LRM file, or for instance to access the contents of an LRM package.

The LRM package is unbundled to a temporary directory on the first call to FileExists or GetFileStream. This temporary directory is maintained for the life of the LrmPackageReader, and is deleted in the Dispose or finalizer. The identity passed into the constructor, or the current user must have permissions to allow unbundling and reading the package files in the temporary directory.
See PackageReader for examples of how classes based on PackageReader (such as this one) can be used.
The LrmPackageReader class calls unmanaged code. Since this assembly is used in the GAC, it has unmanaged code permissions implicitly.
The FileSystemPackageReader and LrmPackageReader classes both require FileIOPermission to write to the file system. Again, this is implicit as this assembly is a "full trust" assembly.

member.summary: A stream containing the package.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the LrmPackageReader class with the specified LRM package. Uses the current user's identity to access files in the package.
member.param: The path to the LRM file containing the package, e.g. "C:\Foo\Bar.lrm".

remarks.para: This constructor does not check if the file exists. This constructor is a placeholder for a string that is used to access the file in subsequent operations.
The parameter can be a directory on a network file share accessible via a mapped drive letter or UNC path.

member.exception: is a null reference.

member.name: T:Microsoft.LearningComponents.ZipPackageReader
member.summary: Provides read-only access to the files contained within a single package that is stored in a zipped file on the file system.

remarks.para: The zipped package can be stored on the local hard drive, removable storage, or on a network file share accessible via a mapped drive letter or UNC path. However, note that performance may be very poor if the file name is a UNC path.
This class can be used to import a package contained in a zipped file, or for instance to access the contents of a zipped package.

The zipped package is unzipped to a temporary directory on the first call to FileExists or GetFileStream. This temporary directory is maintained for the life of the ZipPackageReader, and is deleted in the Dispose or finalizer.
See PackageReader for examples of how classes based on PackageReader (such as this one) can be used.
The ZipPackageReader class calls unmanaged code. Since this assembly is used in the GAC, it has unmanaged code permissions implicitly.
The FileSystemPackageReader and ZipPackageReader classes both require FileIOPermission to write to the file system. Again, this is implicit as this assembly is a "full trust" assembly.

member.name: M:Microsoft.LearningComponents.RloRenderContext.SetOutputStreamExtension(System.String)
member.summary: Set the file extension for the output stream. If there is a Response object, the mime type is set on the response.
member.param: The extension of the filename that is being rendered. This is of the form ".htm", including the period.

member.name: M:Microsoft.LearningComponents.RloRenderContext.WriteFileToResponse(System.String)
member.summary: Writes the file from the package directly to the response and set the appropriate content type in the response. If the response is provided and the path extension is not in the list of files to use IIS compatibility mode, this is much faster than copying the file contents to the output stream and should be used whenever possible. If there is no response object, the method reverts to copying the file between streams.
member.param: The package-relative path to the file to render.

member.name: M:Microsoft.LearningComponents.RloRenderContext.WriteFileToResponse(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Writes the file from a byte array directly to the response. The output stream extension must be set prior to calling this method. If the response is provided and the path extension is not in the list of files to use IIS compatibility mode, this is much faster than copying the file contents to the output stream and should be used whenever possible. If there is no response object, the method reverts to copying the file between streams.
member.param: The file to render.

member.name: M:Microsoft.LearningComponents.RloRenderContext.WriteIisCompatibilityModeToResponse(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Write the stream to the response, using WriteBinary. This method closes the stream.

member.name: M:Microsoft.LearningComponents.RloRenderContext.UseCompatibilityMode(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if IIS compatibility mode should be used for sending this file. 'Compatibility mode' indicates the code should not use TransmitFile to send the requested file.
member.param: The extension, including preceding period, of a file to render
member.returns: True if IIS compatiblity mode should be used for this file type.

member.name: P:Microsoft.LearningComponents.RloRenderContext.IsResourceEntryPoint
member.summary: Returns true if the requested RelativePath is the entry point for the current activity

member.name: P:Microsoft.LearningComponents.RloRenderContext.EmbeddedUIResourcePath
member.summary: Get the location of resources embedded in the rendered content that are not contained within the content. This will not be null.
member.remarks: The value will be either an absolute path or a relative path. If relative, the path must begin with "./" and end without a "/". E.g. "./", "./path" are legal values. If not set explicitly, will be the relative path "./".

member.name: P:Microsoft.LearningComponents.RloRenderContext.FormHiddenControls
member.summary: Gets the list of hidden controls to render in the form. The key is the id of the control, the value is the value of the control. Both strings are provided in plain text (not HTML).

member.name: P:Microsoft.LearningComponents.RloRenderContext.ScriptToRender
member.summary: Gets the jscript to render in the page. The returned string will not include the <script> delimiters. The rendered page should ensure this script is rendered in a way that will cause it to run before the user can interact with the page but after the page has been processed by the browser for rendering. For instance, the script should be added to an onload handler or in-page script at the end of the file.
member.remarks: The value of this property is valid jscript and can be rendered directly in the page without further encoding.

member.name: P:Microsoft.LearningComponents.RloRenderContext.ShowCorrectAnswers
member.summary: Get a value indicating whether correct answers should be displayed in the content, if possible. Regardless of this value, answers may only be shown if it is supported in the current activity format for the current LearningSession.View.
member.remarks: This setting only affects content which is dynamically rendered, such as Lrm content, and only in Review and Grading views. In other views and content formats, the setting is ignored.

member.name: P:Microsoft.LearningComponents.RloRenderContext.ShowReviewerInformation
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether sections of the content intended for a reviewer of a session (and not the learner) should be displayed in the rendered content.
member.remarks: This setting only affects content which is dynamically rendered, such as Lrm content, and only in Review and Grading views. In other views and content formats, the setting is ignored.

member.name: T:Microsoft.LearningComponents.HtmlString
member.summary: Represents HTML markup, i.e. a series of Unicode characters intended to be written to an HTML file and read by a Web browser.
member.remarks: /System.String can be used to represent many kinds of strings of Unicode characters: plain text, HTML markup, URLs, etc. While that flexibility is convenient, it comes at a cost: it's too easy to pass the wrong type of string from one piece of code to another (for example, to a method from its caller). This can lead to incorrect results, depending on the input data, and may even result in security bugs such as script insertion vulnerabilities. Bugs can be caused by (a) a developer not understanding all the subtleties of string encoding, and/or (b) misunderstanding a method's "contract" (i.e. comments defining legal inputs, outputs, and side effects). The following simple example (a helper method in a C# ASP.NET application) illustrates both problems: /// /// Outputs HTML consisting of an anchor element which, when clicked, /// displays given text within a JScript alert. /// /// /// Text of the link. /// /// Text to display in the alert. /// void WriteAlertLink(string linkText, string alertText) { Response.Write(String.Format("{1}", alertText, linkText)); } Calling the function as follows: WriteAlertLink("Click me!", "Thanks for clicking me."); will generate a "Click me!" link which, when clicked, correctly displays the following: WriteAlertLink_1.gif So far so good. Unfortunately, calling the method as follows: WriteAlertLink("Select©", @"See C:\100%BEEF\*.txt"); generates an odd-looking link "Select" which, when clicked, displays the following: WriteAlertLink_2.gif Worse yet, calling the method as follows: WriteAlertLink("Oops", "That's all, folks!"); generates a script error: WriteAlertLink_3.gif How can there be so many problems in such a simple one-line method? WriteAlertLink has two parameters, and both have problems. The firstand easiest to fixis linkText. Any good developer familiar with HTML can spot the problem here: linkText is not HTML-encoded. A more precise way to think about the problem is that there is a kind of type mismatch: in the examples above, the caller is expecting that linkText is of type "plain text", but in fact linkText is of type "HTML". To fix this problem, either the method contract (header comments) need to change to reflect the fact that the linkText is of type "HTML" (in which case it should probably be named linkHtml, not linkText), or a method such as HttpUtility.HtmlEncode needs to be used to convert linkText from type "HTML" to type "plain text". (In this case, the contract comments should also be updated to clarify that linkText is of type "HTML".) Parameter alertText is more problematic. If the effective type of linkText is HTML, what's the effective type of alertText? To answer that question, recall that WriteAlertLink generates the following HTML: linkText Now, examine what will happen to alertText at runtime, before it is passed to the alert function: When the browser parses the "href" attribute, converts character entity references such as " " and """ into corresponding characters. When the user clicks on the link, the browser notices that the href's protocol is "javascript:", so it: converts any "%xx" hexadecimal escape sequences within "javascript:"... into the corresponding characters, and passes everything after "javascript:" to the JScript interpreter. The JScript interpreter sees a single-quoted string ('alertText') and it: converts any backslash escape sequences such as "\n" and "\007" to the corresponding characters, and generates a script error if there is another single quote (') within alertText. Consider the example where alertText is "See C:\100%BEEF\*.txt" as shown in one of the examples above: #1 doesn't applythere are no character entity references in this string. #2 causes "%BE" in the string to change to "", since Unicode character 0x00BE is "". The result is "See C:\100EF\*.txt". #3 causes "\100" to change to "@", since octal 100 (decimal 64) is the character code for "@". Also, "\*" changes to just "*"that's what JScript does to unknown backslash escape sequences. The result is "See C:@EF*.txt". In the case where alertText is "That's all, folks!", #3 causes a script error due to the embedded single quote. Microsoft.LearningServer.Library addresses the string encoding problem by introducing several classes that serve as "wrappers" for specific kinds of strings: PlainTextString represents text without any encoding or markup, as an end user would see it. HtmlString represents HTML markup, intended to be interpreted by a Web browser. JScriptString represents JScript source code that's intended to be written to a block within an HTML file. UrlString represents a string that can be typed into the address bar of a Web browser. These classes can be used in places where you want to refer to a more specific kind of string. For example, assume the following method is defined: void Foo(HtmlString html) { Console.WriteLine(html); } This method simply copies the HTML markup within the html parameter to the console. (Note that this involes an implicit conversion from HtmlString to /System.Stringthat conversion returns the HTML markup as-is.) Since the argument is of type HtmlString, the following call generates a compiler error: "cannot convert from 'string' to 'HtmlString'". Foo("Select©"); // compiler error Instead, the caller needs to be more explicit about the type of string being passed in. The following two lines produce the same output; in the first case, the string begins as a PlainTextString that is converted to an HtmlString using ../PlainTextString.ToHtmlString; in the second case the string begins as HTML markup. Foo(new PlainTextString("Select©").ToHtmlString()); Foo(new HtmlString("Select&copy")); Defining the argument of Foo as HtmlString instead of simply /System.String has the following advantages: The argument is clearly documented as being an HTML string. Certain encoding errors (such as passing a PlainTextString or /System.String value) can be caught at compile time. Returning to the WriteAlertLink example, the following is a more type-safe version of that method that uses some of the classes in the Microsoft.LearningServer.Library namespace: void WriteAlertLink(HtmlString linkHtml, PlainTextString alertText) { HtmlStringWriter htmlWriter = new HtmlStringWriter(Response.Output); htmlWriter.AddJavascriptProtocolAttribute(HtmlTextWriterAttribute.Href, new JScriptString(String.Format("alert({0})", JScriptString.QuoteString(alertText, true)))); htmlWriter.RenderBeginTag(HtmlTextWriterTag.A); htmlWriter.WriteHtml(linkHtml); htmlWriter.RenderEndTag(); } In addition to using PlainTextString, HtmlString, and JScriptString, the example above demonstrates another Microsoft.LearningServer.Library encoding helper class, HtmlStringWriter, which is similar to /System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter but is more type-safe. See the individual classes used above for more information. The new version of WriteAlertLink shown above is called as follows: WriteAlertLink(new HtmlString("Select&copy"), new PlainTextString(@"See C:\100%BEEF\*.txt")); As expected, this generates a "Select©" hyperlink which, when clicked, displays the following: WriteAlertLink_4.gif You would get the same results by calling WriteAlertLink as follows: WriteAlertLink(new PlainTextString("Select©").ToHtmlString(), new PlainTextString(@"See C:\100%BEEF\*.txt")); In fact, since an implicit conversion is defined between /System.String and PlainTextString, the following also works: WriteAlertLink(new PlainTextString("Select©").ToHtmlString(), @"See C:\100%BEEF\*.txt"); However, the following would generate a compiler error, since there is no implicit conversion between /System.String and HtmlString: WriteAlertLink("Select©", @"See C:\100%BEEF\*.txt"); // compiler error

member.name: T:Microsoft.LearningComponents.JScriptString
member.summary: [Internal class?] Represents JScript source code, i.e. a series of Unicode characters intended to be written into a <script>...</script> block of an HTML file.
member.remarks: Note that JScriptString should not be used to represent a "javascript:" URI. For example, if you place "alert('100%BEEF')" within a <script>...</script> block, you'll get an alert with the message "100%BEEF". However, in "javascript:alert('100%BEEF')" "%BE" is interpreted as character 0xBEif that's not what's intended, "javascript:alert('100%25BEEF') should be used. Use ToJavascriptProtocol to convert from JScriptString to a "javascript:" URI.

member.name: M:Microsoft.LearningComponents.UrlString.ToAscii
member.summary: Converts any non-ASCII characters within the string to UTF-8 and hexadecimal-encoded (%xx) equivalents.
member.returns: An UrlString with non-ASCII characters converted to UTF-8 sequences that are then hexadecimal-encoded.
member.remarks:
If you type "http://localhost/LaNia" into Internet Explorer, it will convert the URL internally to "http://localhost/LaNi%c3%b1a", which is an equivalent representation of the URL that only contains ASCII characters. (You can also type "http://localhost/LaNi%c3%b1a" directly into a browser—doing so will navigate to the same document.)
This method converts any non-ASCII character within the string to UTF-8 and hexadecimal-encoded (%xx) equivalents. For example, "" is converted to "%c3%b1".
If the URL doesn't contain non-ASCII characters, the output of this method is the same as its input. Example:
UrlString url1 = new UrlString("http://localhost/LaNia"); UrlString url2 = url1.ToAscii(); // returns "http://localhost/LaNi%c3%b1a" UrlString url3 = url2.ToAscii(); // returns "http://localhost/LaNi%c3%b1a"
ToAscii does not fully "canonicalize" the URL. In particular, the space character is not converted to "%20".
member.example:
The following code:
Console.WriteLine(new UrlString("http://localhost/LaNia").ToAscii());
writes the following output:
http://localhost/LaNi%c3%b1a

member.name: M:Microsoft.LearningComponents.UrlString.ToUnicode
member.summary: Converts hexadecimal-encoded (%xx) non-ASCII UTF-8 sequences within a string to the Unicode equivalents.
member.returns: An UrlString with hexadecimal-encoded non-ASCII UTF-8 sequences converted to Unicode equivalents.
member.remarks:
This method looks for non-ASCII URL-encoded bytes within runs of hexadecimal-encoded (%xx) sequences in the string and converts those bytes to Unicode characters. For example, "%c3%b1" is converted to "", since byte 0xc3 followed by byte 0xb1 is the UTF-8 encoding for the character "". However, for example, "%20" is left unmodified.
A characteristic of this method is that it converts an URL to an URL that's semantically equivalent: typing the string returned by the method into the address bar of Internet Explorer will yield the same result (i.e. navigate to the same location) as typing the input string.
Unlike /System.Web.HttpUtility.UrlDecode, this method does not change "+" to " " (space). Doing so might change the meaning of the URL, since "+" and " " aren't treated as the same character when they are part of the path component of the URL. For example, although the following URLs point to the same location:
http://localhost/Foo.aspx?X=A B http://localhost/Foo.aspx?X=A+B
the following URLs point to different locations:
http://localhost/A B.aspx http://localhost/A+B.aspx
Similarly, this method does not decode "%25" into "%". If it did, then calling this method on the following URL:
http://localhost/LaNi%25c3%25b1a.htm
would yield the following result:
http://localhost/LaNi%c3%b1a.htm
which has a different meaning. (The first URL refers to a document named "La%c3%25a.htm"—i.e. the file name itself contains "%" characters—while the second URL refers to a document named named "LaNia.htm".)
Characters that do not correspond to hexadecimal characters are not modified. For example, "%JK" is not modified.
member.example:
The following code:
Console.WriteLine(new UrlString("http://localhost/LaNi%c3%b1a").ToUnicode());
writes the following output:
http://localhost/LaNia

member.name: M:Microsoft.LearningComponents.UrlString.EndUnicodeRun(System.Byte[],System.Int32@,System.Text.StringBuilder,System.Boolean,System.Boolean@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Process a character that indicates it is the end of a unicode run. The method writes the current character (or, optionally the remainder of the string) in m_url and puts it into the output buffer after first writing the characters in the unicode run.
member.param: The list of bytes that were part of the run. They will be written to the output buffer. The list cannot be null, but may be empty.
Number of bytes in the array. (This is not the size of the array, but rather the number of bytes stored in the array.)
The output buffer to flush the unicode run and current character. It cannot be null.
If true, the remainder of m_url (starting from ich) will be written to the output buffer and ich is incremented accordingly.
Bool indicating whether currently in the midst of a run of unicode chars. On return, this will be set to false.
The position of the current character in m_url.

member.name: T:Microsoft.LearningComponents.HtmlTextReader.HtmlNodeParser
member.summary: State-machine class that parses a StreamReader, character-by-character, for HTML and XML. From a macro view, it is always in one of two states: between nodes or parsing a node. The main parsing routine is HtmlNodeParser.Parse. If the parser's state is "between nodes" upon entering this method, upon exiting the method (assuming there is another node to parse) the state will usually be parsing a node. This is because it exits as soon as it knows the type of node being parsed, which usually won't take until the end of the node. If the parser's state is "parsing a node" upon entry, upon exit the state will be "between nodes."
member.remarks: Call Close when done to dispose of the StreamWriter's.

member.summary: Returns the Html/Xml of the current Element up to its corresponding EndElement, unless the current Element is an empty element (e.g. ends with a /> and not just a >). If it is an empty element, returns only the current Element.
member.returns: Returns a TextReader that gives access to the HTML (or XML as the case may be) from the current node (which must be an Element node) to the corresponding EndElement node (or the end of the file if the EndElement doesn't exist.)
member.remarks: After calling this method, the state of the parser will be that the current note type is "none."
member.exception: If the node type isn't an Element node, or the node's name is blank.

member.name: M:Microsoft.LearningComponents.HtmlTextReader.HtmlNodeParser.Parse
member.summary: Parses the next section of the stream.
member.remarks:
Throws EndOfStreamException when it hits the end of the stream without finishing parsing a full node.
On entry to this method: m_ParseMode must be set.
On exit from this method: m_AttributeLineNumber is set m_AttributeLinePosition is set m_ParseState is set m_NodeType is set if a new node is parsed. m_Reader is advanced to either the end of the currently parsing node, or just enough of the newly parsing node to recognize the type of node it is.

member.name: M:Microsoft.LearningComponents.Utilities.StringToTimeSpanScormV1p3(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a SCORM 2004 Timespan string into a TimeSpan.
member.param: A length of time in hours, minutes and seconds shown in the following format: P[yY][mM][dD][T[hH][mM][s[.s]S]] with a precision of 0.01 seconds.
member.returns: The corresponding TimeSpan. If is null or String.Empty, this returns TimeSpan.MaxValue.
member.exception: is in an incorrect format. No message is included in the exception.

remarks.para: XmlConvert.ToTimeSpan() will not work for converting SCORM 2004 values (which are also ISO 8601 values) since XmlConvert uses an incorrect value for days per year and days per month. XmlConvert.ToString(TimeSpan) will produce a correct equivalent, however.

1 year ~ (365*4+1)/4*60*60*24*100 = 3155760000 centiseconds 1 month ~ (365*4+1)/48*60*60*24*100 = 262980000 centiseconds 1 day = 8640000 centiseconds 1 hour = 360000 centiseconds 1 minute = 6000 centiseconds

member.name: M:Microsoft.LearningComponents.Utilities.StringToTimeSpanScormV1p2(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a SCORM 1.2 Timespan string into a TimeSpan.
member.param: A length of time in hours, minutes and seconds shown in the following numerical format: HHHH:MM:SS.SS. Hours has a minimum of 2 digits and a maximum of 4 digits. Minutes shall consist of exactly 2 digits. Seconds shall contain 2 digits, with an optional decimal point and 1 or 2 additional digits.
member.returns: The corresponding TimeSpan. If is null or String.Empty, this returns TimeSpan.MaxValue.
member.exception: is in an incorrect format. No message is included in the exception.

member.name: M:Microsoft.LearningComponents.Utilities.StringToXPathLiteral(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a string to an XPath literal.

remarks.para: For example, the string "Abc'123'Def" converts to "\"Abc'123'Def\"".
XPath defines a literal string as a string between two double quotes that contains no double quotes or a string between two single quotes that contains no single quotes.

This works well for most cases, but if the string in question contains both single and double quotes, we have some work to do. We get around this by using the built-in concat() function to concatenate the string fragments without double-quotes along with double-quotes in single-quoted strings.

member.param: The string to verify
member.returns: A properly quoted string or equivalent expression.

member.name: T:Microsoft.LearningComponents.ManifestValidator
member.summary: ManifestValidator validates that the contents of the manifest conforms to the SCORM requirements, for those manifest elements and attributes that are relevant to Microsoft Learning Components.
member.remarks: ManifestValidator does not attempt to validate that files external to the manifest exist in the locations indicated in the manifest. Use PackageValidator for that level of validation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.LearningComponents.ManifestValidator.Validate(Microsoft.LearningComponents.Manifest.ManifestReader)
member.summary: Validate the manifest. Errors and warnings are returned in the results
member.param: The ManifestReader to validate.

member.name: T:Microsoft.LearningComponents.PackageValidator
member.summary: PackageValidator detects variances with the SCORM specification.
member.remarks:
Given a SCORM package, the PackageValidator will verify that the manifest is correct (using the ManifestValidator object) and verify that the files referenced in the manifest are actually present in the package.
The PackageValidator does not verify that files referenced within assets and not within the package manifest are present in the package. Put another way: the PackageValidator does not read or parse the contents of any file (other than the manifest) within the package.
Definitions: Error = A required node in a SCORM package either does not exist or does not have an appropriate value. Warning = A SCORM recommendation is not followed in the package or an optional value in the package has an invalid value.

member.name: M:Microsoft.LearningComponents.PackageValidator.Validate(Microsoft.LearningComponents.PackageReader,Microsoft.LearningComponents.PackageValidatorSettings)
member.summary: Validate a package according to specific validation settings.
member.remarks: The ValidationResults log will contain the warnings and errors encountered during the package validation process, up to any InvalidPackageException that is thrown during the process, at which time the validation process ends.
member.returns: A ValidationResults log that contains the warnings and errors encountered during the package validation process.
member.param: The PackageValidatorSettings determining which validation rules should be applied during the validation process.
The package to be valdated.
member.exception: Thrown if the is null.
Thrown if the validation process encounters errors in the package for which the have a ValidationBehavior value of ValidationBehavior.Enforce.
